Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 49002-001 
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
January 2016 
 
 
Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: Capacity for 
Regional Economic Integration 
(Cofinanced by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund)  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This  document  is  being  disclosed  to  the  public  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Public 
Communications Policy 2011. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency of Timor-Leste is the United States dollar.  
 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  MFAC  –  Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation 
  REI  –  regional economic integration 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
   
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  X. Yao, Pacific Department (PARD) 
   
Team leader  S. Rosenthal, Country Director, Timor-Leste Resident Mission (TLRM), 
PARD 
Team member  M. Caldeira, Senior Operations Assistant, TLRM (PARD)

designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been supporting the development of Timor-
Leste’s capacity for regional economic integration since 2013. Assistance has been provided 
through a 3-year capacity development technical assistance (TA) project financed by the Japan 
Fund for Poverty Reduction.1 Responsibility for project administration was transferred to ADB’s 
Timor-Leste Resident Mission in November 2014. The project is scheduled for completion in 
early 2016. It has made good progress in building capacity for regional integration and has 
supported important analytical work.   
 
2.  The  government  appreciates  the  initial  TA  and  has  requested  ADB  to  continue  to 
support  its  preparations  for  regional  economic  integration,  with  a  focus  on  achieving  full 
membership  in  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN).  A  new  capacity 
development TA project was included in the nonlending pipeline of the country operations 
business plan, 2015–2017.2 The TA will enable a smooth continuation of ADB support following 
completion of the current project.  
 
3.  TLRM  staff  meet  regularly  with  government  officials  responsible  for  Timor-Leste’s 
regional cooperation and integration to discuss implementation of the current TA project and 
future TA needs. A fact-finding mission was fielded from 24 October to 9 November 2015 to 
confirm the objectives and design of the new TA. The government has confirmed the impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference presented in this report.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Regional cooperation and integration is an important part of Timor-Leste’s strategy to 
grow the non-oil economy. The petroleum sector has accounted for up to 84% of total gross 
domestic product, but production from current fields is declining and the prospects for new 
developments are uncertain. Government spending underpins the non-oil economy. The private 
sector is nascent and is constrained by limited human capital, poor quality infrastructure, and 
gaps in the basic legal framework for commerce. The government is working to address these 
constraints and is targeting regional integration as a means of promoting trade, investment, and 
labor market linkages that will support economic diversification.  
 
5.  ASEAN  membership  is  Timor-Leste’s  principal  regional  cooperation  and  integration 
objective. Timor-Leste formally applied for membership in 2011, and aims to become a full and 
active member. It also participates in Pacific regional fora, is pursuing subregional integration 
with  Australia  and  Indonesia,  and  is  considering  an  application  to  join  the  World  Trade 
Organization. These regional cooperation and integration initiatives may have synergies if they 
are appropriately coordinated and sequenced.  
 
6.  The  ASEAN  Charter  establishes  four  conditions  for  membership:  (i)  location  within 
Southeast Asia, (ii) recognition by all ASEAN member states, (iii) agreement to be bound and to 
abide by the ASEAN Charter, and (iv) ability and willingness to carry out the obligations of 
membership. Meeting the fourth condition will be challenging for Timor-Leste. ASEAN’s move 
                                                
1  ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Preparing for Regional Economic 
Integration. Manila.  
2  ADB. 2014. Country Operations Business Plan: Timor-Leste, 2015–2017. Manila.

2                  
 
toward deeper cooperation and integration means that accession is more technically demanding 
now than when Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, and Viet Nam 
joined in the 1990s. 
 
7.  A new ASEAN member would be required to accede to at least 64 substantive legal 
treaties, and make the necessary changes to domestic legislation to ensure consistency. A new 
member must also show commitment to ASEAN policy objectives not captured in these treaties, 
and develop the capacity to participate meaningfully in ASEAN’s technical working meetings. 
Effective and regular participation in relevant working meetings is directly tied with Timor-Leste’s 
ability to carry out the obligations of ASEAN membership.3 
 
8.  The Government of Timor-Leste is preparing for ASEAN accession. It has strengthened 
its diplomatic and economic relations with ASEAN member countries, established a system of 
focal points in relevant line ministries, and carried out public awareness programs. ADB has 
provided TA to support capacity building, analysis of the economic implications of ASEAN 
accession, and comprehensive analysis of Timor-Leste’s current laws and policies and the 
reforms needed to meet current ASEAN requirements.   
 
9.  The Government of Timor-Leste has requested additional TA to support the preparations 
for ASEAN accession. The key issues to be addressed in the next phase of assistance are 
(i) limited technical understanding of the requirements and implications of ASEAN accession 
and other regional integration initiatives, (ii) limited capacity to plan and implement required 
reforms and participate in regional integration, and (iii) gaps in the systems for coordination and 
communications to support ASEAN accession. Addressing these issues would support the 
broader objective of improving the business environment and growing the non-oil economy.4 
Timor-Leste is well positioned to achieve its goal of ASEAN membership, but the benefits of the 
TA are not conditional on this.  
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be Timor-Leste becoming a full member of ASEAN. The outcome will be 
an improvement in Timor-Leste’s ability to meet ASEAN’s requirements and be a full and active 
ASEAN member. This encompasses changes to Timor-Leste’s legal and regulatory frameworks, 
the  development  of  individual  and  institutional  capacities,  and  the  coordination  of 
complementary initiatives across a wide range of government and nongovernment institutions.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA  outcome  will  be  achieved  through the  delivery  of four  interrelated  outputs: 
(i) enhanced  understanding  of  the  requirements  and  implications  of  ASEAN  membership, 
(ii) successful implementation of legal and regulatory reforms to meet ASEAN requirements, 
(iii) improved  individual  and  institutional  capacity  to  meet  ASEAN  requirements,  and 
(iv) effective communications with domestic and international stakeholders during the accession 
process.  
                                                
3  In the event that ASEAN sets out a gradual path to full membership, the frequency and quality of participation in 
meetings may be linked, formally or informally, to successful progression. 
4  Government of Timor-Leste. 2011. Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan, 2011–2030. Dili.

33 
 
 
12.  Output 1. Basic understanding about ASEAN has improved, but many key government 
stakeholders lack the detailed understanding needed to (i) design appropriate reform programs, 
(ii) identify priorities in the event that Timor-Leste can negotiate the terms of its accession, and 
(iii) plan and implement supporting reforms to maximize the benefits of ASEAN accession. The 
TA will address these gaps through the following key activities: 
(i)  detailed analysis of the alignment of Timor-Leste’s current legal and regulatory 
frameworks with the requirements under the ASEAN Community Blueprints and 
ASEAN legal instruments;  
(ii)  training  and  awareness-raising  programs  for  government  officials, 
nongovernment organizations and civil society, the private sector, and the public, 
to build familiarity with ASEAN and the requirements and implications of Timor-
Leste’s accession;  
(iii)  provision  of  technical  training  and  capacity  building  to  selected  government 
ministries  and  agencies  to  support  improved  understanding  of  ASEAN 
requirements that fall within their mandates, and the implications of required 
reforms; and 
(iv)  analysis of conditioning reforms that are not compulsory for ASEAN accession 
but can help to leverage the benefits of accession.  
 
13.  Output  2.  The  achievement  of  full  ASEAN  membership  will  require  successful 
implementation of legal and regulatory reforms to meet ASEAN requirements. Previous TA from 
ADB and the Japan International Cooperation Agency has supported the mapping of relevant 
laws  and  regulatory  arrangements,  and  high-level  analysis  of  reform  requirements.5 This 
analysis will be used to develop a time-bound program of legal and regulatory reforms to 
achieve full compliance with ASEAN requirements. The TA will also support the design and 
implementation of a scalable pilot activity to accelerate integration with ASEAN members.6 This 
could be implemented by identifying gaps and constraints on trade between Timor-Leste and 
ASEAN members, building institutional capacity to address key constraints, and identifying 
possible investment opportunities to address gaps. Other potential pilot activities will also be 
considered. Key activities under output 2 will include the following:  
(i)  finalization of an overall time-bound reform program and the development of 
work plans for subcomponents;  
(ii)  mapping of external sources of technical and financial assistance to support 
implementation of the reform program;  
(iii)  design and implementation of a scalable pilot activity to accelerate Timor-Leste’s 
ASEAN readiness;  
(iv)  support  for  the  establishment  and  operation  of  coordination  mechanisms  for 
reforms that involve multiple government and nongovernment stakeholders, such 
as the establishment of a National Committee on Trade Facilitation;   
(v)  support to the Directorate for ASEAN Affairs to coordinate the reform program, 
monitor implementation progress, and prepare regular implementation reports; 
and 
(vi)  technical inputs to support selected legal and policy reforms where the support 
available from other sources is insufficient.  
                                                
5   See footnote 1 
6  A national single window provides a single entry point through which traders can submit all the necessary 
documentation and data required for the import or export of goods, and a single decision-making point for customs 
release  and  clearance.  The  ASEAN  Single  Window  is  a  platform  to  achieve  integration  and  technical 
interoperability of the national single windows of ASEAN member countries.

4                  
 
 
14.  Output  3.  The  TA  will  build  individual  and  institutional  capacity  to  meet  ASEAN 
requirements. Substantial human resources will be needed for Timor-Leste to meet its goal of 
being an active and valued ASEAN member. The TA will help the government and its agencies 
to understand their capacity requirements and design and implement programs to meet these 
requirements. Key activities under this output will include the following:  
(i)  needs assessment and the development of an overall framework for training and 
capacity development;  
(ii)  mapping of resources available to support capacity development and training;  
(iii)  support for strengthening of the ASEAN focal point system, including capacity 
assessments of the focal points, and targeted training to address knowledge and 
skill gaps;  
(iv)  support  for  increased  participation  of  government  officials  as  observers  at 
ASEAN  meetings,  including  mapping  and  prioritization  of  opportunities  for 
increased  participation,  and  training  and  mentoring  support  for  participating 
officials;  
(v)  support to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation and its Directorate of 
ASEAN  Affairs  to  coordinate  internal  and  externally  supported  capacity 
development and training programs; and  
(vi)  direct provision of training and capacity development to address areas where the 
support available from other sources is insufficient. 
 
15.   Output 4. Effective communications with domestic and international stakeholders are a 
key enabler of ASEAN accession. They will underpin the implementation and coordination of 
legal and regulatory reform, and ensure effective collection and dissemination of information to 
domestic  and  international  stakeholders.  The  TA  will  support  effective  communications  by 
completing the following key activities:  
(i)  review of the communications strategy to support ASEAN accession;  
(ii)  maintenance  of  a  map  of  stakeholders  in  Timor-Leste’s  ASEAN  accession 
process;   
(iii)  support  for  regular  consultation  and  communication  with  nongovernment 
organizations and civil society, the private sector, and the public; and 
(iv)  support  for  communications  with  international  stakeholders  in  Timor-Leste’s 
accession  including  ASEAN  members,  the  ASEAN  Secretariat,  and  other 
partners.  
 
16.  The methodology and activities assume that current ASEAN member states are willing 
to  accept  Timor-Leste  as  a  member  and  that  the  Government  of  Timor-Leste  will  remain 
committed to membership. Successful implementation of TA activities and the transformation of 
activities into outputs, outcomes, and impacts would all be threatened by the failure of these two 
assumptions. However, both these risks are assessed as having very low probability.  
 
17.  Other risks include delays in the planning and implementation of TA outputs resulting 
from  capacity  constraints,  competing  commitments,  and  insufficient  ownership  of  planned 
reforms. These risks will be managed by adopting a consultative and participatory process 
during TA inception; integrating the planning and implementation of TA outputs into broader 
national frameworks for policy formation, legal reform, and capacity development; emphasizing 
realistic  planning;  and  incorporating  measurable  progress  indicators  into  the  plans  for  TA 
implementation.

55 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA amount is estimated at $1,000,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund7 and $500,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office and accommodation, office 
supplies, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, and will be responsible for all recruitment 
of consultants and procurement. This will be done in consultation with the Ministry of Foreign 
Affairs and Cooperation, which is mandated to coordinate Timor-Leste’s preparation for ASEAN 
membership. The ministry will be the implementing agency, with support from consultants, and 
will coordinate TA-supported activities with other line ministries and government agencies. The 
director general for ASEAN affairs will provide overall guidance and supervision of TA activities. 
In the absence of a director general, the responsibility for guidance and oversight will be given 
to the national director for the ASEAN economic community.    
 
20.  All TA consultants will be recruited as individuals because of the specialized nature of 
the tasks. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The total consulting services will include 
54 person-months of international consultants and 48 person-months of national consultants 
comprising (i) international team leader (24 person-months), (ii) national deputy team leader 
(24 person-months), (iii) national communications and liaison officer (24 person-months), (iv) 
international senior legal adviser (12 person-months), and (v) international technical specialists 
(18 person-months). All TA consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). All procurement will be carried 
out  according  to  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2015,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Technical specialists will be 
engaged as resource persons to support workshops, knowledge sharing, and training events. 
This modality will not be used to finance ADB staff participation in TA activities.  
 
21.  TA implementation will draw on ADB’s expertise in regional cooperation and integration. 
A panel of ADB regional cooperation and integration specialists will be formed to provide peer 
review and guidance during TA implementation and to foster linkages between TA activities and 
ADB’s other programs to support regional integration. Progress in delivering TA outputs will be 
monitored by ADB specialists during TA implementation, and outputs and outcomes will be 
evaluated upon TA completion.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION   
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund, and (ii) ADB 
providing  the  balance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $500,000  on  a  grant  basis,  to  the 
Government of Timor-Leste for Capacity for Regional Economic Integration, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.  
                                                
7 Established by ADB. Financing partner: the Government of Japan.

 Key Activities with Milestones 
1.   Enhanced understanding of the requirements and implications of ASEAN membership 
1.1 Detailed analysis of the alignment of Timor-Leste’s current legal and regulatory frameworks with the 
requirements under the ASEAN Community Blueprints and ASEAN legal instruments (completed by 
end of Q2 2016). 
1.2 Training and awareness-raising programs for government officials, nongovernment organizations and 
civil society, the private sector, and the public, to build familiarity with ASEAN and the requirements 
and implications of Timor-Leste’s accession (ongoing throughout TA). 
1.3 Provision of technical training and capacity building to selected government ministries and agencies 
to support improved understanding of ASEAN requirements that fall within their mandates, and the 
implications of required reforms (ongoing throughout TA). 
1.4 Analysis of supporting reforms that is not compulsory for ASEAN accession but can help to leverage 
the benefits of accession (initial analysis by end of Q2 2016 with updates in 2017 and 2018). 
2.   Successful implementation of a program of legal and regulatory reforms to meet ASEAN 
requirements 
2.1 Finalization of an overall time-bound reform program and development of work plans for 
subcomponents (completed by end of Q2 2016). 
2.2 Design of a scalable pilot activity to accelerate Timor-Leste’s ASEAN readiness that can be 
implemented in partnership with one or more ASEAN member countries (completed by end 2016). 
2.3 Mapping of external sources of technical and financial assistance to support implementation of the 
reform program (completed by end of Q1 2016). 
2.4 Support for establishment and operation of coordination mechanisms for reforms that involve multiple 
government and nongovernment stakeholders, such as establishment of a National Committee on 
Trade Facilitation (completed by end of Q1 2016 and ongoing throughout TA). 
2.5 Support to the Directorate for ASEAN Affairs to coordinate the reform program, monitor 
implementation progress, and prepare regular implementation reports (ongoing throughout TA). 
2.6 Technical inputs to support selected legal and policy reforms where the support available from other 
sources is not sufficient (beginning in Q2 2016 and continuing throughout TA).  
2.7 Implementation of a scalable pilot activity to accelerate ASEAN readiness in partnership with one or 
more ASEAN members (beginning Q1 2017 and continuing until completion).

8     Appendix 1             
 
3.   Improved individual and institutional capacity to meet ASEAN requirements 
3.1 Needs assessment and development of an overall framework for training and capacity development 
(initial report in Q2 2016 with 6-monthly updates for remainder of TA).  
3.2 Mapping of resources available to support capacity development and training (completed by end of 
Q1 2016). 
3.3 Support for strengthening of the ASEAN focal point system, including capacity assessments of the 
focal points, and targeted training to address knowledge and skill gaps (ongoing throughout TA). 
3.4 Support for increased participation of government officials as observers at ASEAN meetings, 
including a mapping and prioritization of opportunities for increased participation, and training and 
mentoring support for participating officials (ongoing throughout TA). 
3.5 Support to the MFAC Directorate of ASEAN Affairs to coordinate internal and externally supported 
capacity development and training programs (ongoing throughout TA). 
3.6 Direct provision of training and capacity development to address areas where the support available 
from other sources is not sufficient (from Q2 2016 to end of TA). 
4.   Effective communications with domestic and international stakeholders during the accession 
process 
4.1 Review and updating of MFAC and the Directorate for ASEAN Affairs’ communications strategy to 
support ASEAN accession (completed by end of Q2 2016 with additional reviews in 2017 and 2018).  
4.2 Maintenance of a map of stakeholders in Timor-Leste’s ASEAN accession process (ongoing 
throughout TA). 
4.3 Support for regular consultation and communication with nongovernment organizations and civil 
society, the private sector, and the public (ongoing throughout TA). 
4.4 Support for communications with international stakeholders in Timor-Leste’s accession, including 
ASEAN members, the ASEAN Secretariat, and other partners (ongoing throughout TA). 
Inputs 
ADB: $500,000 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund: $500,000 
Note: The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, office supplies, and other in-kind contributions. 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, ASEAN = Association of Southeast Asian Nations, MFAC = Ministry of Foreign 
Affairs and Cooperation, Q = quarter, TA = technical assistance.  
a  Government of Timor-Leste. 2011. Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan, 2011–2030. Dili.  
Source: Asian Development Bank.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A  consultant  team  will  be  established  within  the  Directorate  for  the  Association  of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation 
(MFAC). A team leader, deputy team leader, and communications specialist will assist the 
directorate on a day-to-day basis with the design and implementation of a time-bound work plan 
to prepare for ASEAN membership and other regional economic integration (REI) initiatives.  
2.   The team leader and deputy team leader will coordinate the inputs of a senior legal 
advisor who will visit Timor-Leste periodically and a group of short-term technical specialists 
who  will  contribute  specific  expertise  needed to  design  and  implement  priority  reform  and 
capacity development programs. The team leader and deputy team leader will also assist the 
directorate with the coordination of other development partner support for REI.  
 
3.   Team leader (international, up to 24 person-months, intermittent). The team leader will 
report to the director general of the MFAC’s Directorate of ASEAN Affairs (or their delegate) and 
hold overall responsibility for technical assistance (TA) implementation. The team leader will 
have a postgraduate degree in economics, law, public policy or political science, or a closely 
related field, and have at least 10 years of experience in regional cooperation and integration 
initiatives.  A  strong  background  in  ASEAN  initiatives  is  essential,  preferably  gained  within 
relevant national or regional organizations. Fluency in English is essential. Fluency in Tetum or 
Bahasa Indonesia would be an advantage.  
4.   Based  in  Dili,  Timor-Leste  at  the  MFAC’s  Directorate  of  ASEAN  Affairs,  the  team 
leader’s specific tasks will include the following:  
(i)  take responsibility for the overall development and implementation of the TA 
under  the  guidance  of  the  directorate,  including  coordination,  capacity 
development and training, communication, information sharing, and dialogue with 
line ministries and their ASEAN focal points;  
(ii)   support the directorate to prepare a detailed work plan for delivery of the TA 
activities and outputs;   
(iii)   assist  the  directorate  to  develop  and  implement  the  reform  and  capacity 
development programs, including through the identification and engagement of 
additional specialist technical expertise required for the implementation of priority 
initiatives;  
(iv)  identify and engage partner institutions and individuals that can help plan and 
implement relevant policy reviews and analysis, training, and knowledge sharing;  
(v)  assist  the  directorate  with  reporting  on  the  implementation  of  capacity 
development and reform programs;  
(vi)  support the directorate in establishing an effective communication system that 
will  raise  the  awareness  of  government  and  external  stakeholders  of  REI 
initiatives, including through the conduct of seminars, workshops, and preparing 
knowledge products and other information releases;  
(vii)  facilitate dialogue events with international stakeholders, including securing the 
support  of  specialists  from  ASEAN  and  ASEAN+3  member  countries1 and 
regional  institutions  to  participate  in  training,  seminars,  conferences,  and 
workshops in Timor-Leste; and  
                                                
1 The ASEAN+3 includes the 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Brunei Darussalam, 
Cambodia,  Indonesia,  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic,  Malaysia,  Myanmar,  the  Philippines,  Singapore, 
Thailand, and Viet Nam) plus the People’s Republic of China, Japan, and Republic of Korea

Appendix 3  11 
(viii)  transfer skills and build the capacity of the director general and directors of the 
directorate so they can take on the responsibilities of the team leader upon 
completion of the TA.  
 
5.   The team leader will also be responsible for the following tasks:  
(i)  lead  the  TA  implementation  in  accordance  with  the  terms  and  conditions 
specified in the agreement between the government and the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB);  
(ii)  coordinate and manage the inputs, activities, and outputs of TA consultants, 
including the allocation of responsibilities between consultants, the administration 
of all contracts under the TA, and monitoring the performance of all consultants;  
(iii)  manage TA resources to achieve the results sought by the design and monitoring 
framework, including initiating and leading discussions of key implementation 
issues  with  the  government,  and  managing  TA  quality  control  and  quality 
assurance;  
(iv)  organize TA inception and concluding workshops with senior representatives of 
the government, other government officials, and relevant stakeholders to inform 
the preparation and/or review of the TA;  
(v)  prepare and monitor progress against a risk management plan that will identify 
key risks to sustainability and the actions required to minimize these risks;  
(vi)  ensure  timely  preparation  and  submission  of  the  inception  report,  monthly 
progress reports, the midterm report, and the project completion report; and 
assist with TA reviews undertaken by ADB and the government;  
(vii)  consult with development partners on TA activities, ensuring that development 
partners are frequently informed of activities and that a high level of coordination 
is maintained that avoids duplication or overlap of work; and  
(viii)  undertake other tasks as required by the directorate, and as may be required for 
successful TA implementation.  
 
6.  Deputy team leader (national, 24 person-months, full time). The deputy team leader will 
report jointly to the director general of the ASEAN Affairs Directorate of MFAC (or their delegate) 
and the team leader. The deputy team leader will have a degree in economics, law, public policy 
or political science, or a closely related field, and have at least 5 years of experience in 
government  or  international  agencies.  A  solid  understanding  of  regional  cooperation  and 
integration would be an advantage. Fluency in Tetum and English is essential. Fluency in 
Portuguese and/or Bahasa Indonesia would be an advantage.  
7.   Based in Dili, Timor-Leste at MFAC’s Directorate of ASEAN Affairs, the deputy team 
leader’s specific tasks will include the following:  
(i)  support  the team  leader  in  the  management  and  implementation  of the TA, 
helping  to  ensure that all  activities  are  implemented  in  accordance with  the 
design and monitoring framework and the terms and conditions specified in the 
agreement between the government and ADB;  
(ii)  assist  the  directorate  in  high-level  dialogue  within  Timor-Leste  on  ASEAN 
accession,  including  support  presentations  to  the  National  Parliament,  the 
Council of Ministers, and other ministerial meetings as required;  
(iii)  help  the  directorate  and  the  team  leader  to  organize  meetings,  seminars, 
dialogue events, and training, including the preparation of knowledge products 
and other information releases;  
(iv)  support  the  team  leader  in  developing  and  maintaining  an  effective 
communication system;

12  Appendix 3 
(v)   collect information and data relevant for Timor-Leste’s membership in ASEAN 
and other REI initiatives, including helping to analyze the information and feeding 
this into policy analysis and reports prepared by the directorate’s TA consultants;  
(vi)  support the team leader in budgeting, financial management and control, human 
resource management, contract management, facilities management, logistics, 
and monitoring, reporting, and record management for the TA implementation; 
and  
(vii)  undertake other tasks as required by the directorate and as may be required for 
successful TA implementation.  
 
8.   Senior legal adviser (international, up to 12 person-months, intermittent). The senior 
legal adviser will report to the director general of MFAC’s Directorate of ASEAN Affairs (or their 
delegate) in coordination with the team leader. The senior legal adviser will have a postgraduate 
degree in economics, law, public policy or political science, or a closely related field, and have 
at least 10 years of experience in regional cooperation and integration initiatives. A strong 
background in the ASEAN or ASEAN+3 initiatives is essential, preferably gained within national 
or regional organizations. Fluency in English is essential.  
9.   Working from  Dili, Timor-Leste  at  the  directorate  and  home  office, the  senior  legal 
adviser will visit Timor-Leste periodically to provide a high-level, strategic review of progress 
toward full ASEAN membership. Specific tasks will include the following:  
(i)  contribute  high-level  expertise  on  policy  issues  raised  by  Timor-Leste’s 
application for ASEAN membership and other REI initiatives;  
(ii)  interact with ministers and senior members of government agencies to provide 
high-level guidance on REI initiatives;  
(iii)  conduct  briefings  and  seminars  with  stakeholders  to  share  experience  and 
disseminate information on REI;  
(iv)  advise on the preparation of knowledge products on REI, and prepare priority 
knowledge products;  
(v)  advise on the progress of the TA and ways of maximizing the contribution of TA 
resources, and resources provided on a coordinated basis by other development 
partners;  
(vi)  document activities in accordance with TA requirements; and  
(vii)  undertake other tasks as required by the directorate and as may be required for 
successful TA implementation.  
 
10.   Technical specialists (up to six positions, international, up to 3 person-months each, 
intermittent). The technical specialists will report to the team leader. The technical specialists 
will have a postgraduate degree in economics, law, public policy or political science, or a closely 
related field, and at least 10 years of relevant experience. A strong background in REI work and 
the ASEAN or ASEAN+3 initiatives is highly desirable. Fluency in English is essential. Fluency 
in Tetum, Portuguese, and/or Bahasa Indonesia would be an advantage.  
11.   Based  in  Dili,  Timor-Leste  at  the  directorate  and  reporting  to the team  leader,  the 
technical specialists will contribute specific expertise needed to design and implement priority 
initiatives of a REI action plan. Specific tasks will include the following:  
(i)  undertake  specific,  results-based  assignments  following  detailed  terms  of 
reference prepared by the team leader;  
(ii)  conduct  briefings  and  seminars  to  disseminate  the  findings  of  specific 
assignments;

Appendix 3  13 
(iii)  advise  on  the  preparation  of knowledge  products  on  ASEAN  accession  and 
regional integration, and prepare priority knowledge products;  
(iv)  document activities in accordance with TA requirements; and  
(v)  undertake other tasks as required by the directorate, and as may be required for 
successful TA implementation.  
 
12.   Communication  and  liaison  officer  (national,  24  person-months,  full  time).  The 
communication and liaison officer will report to the team leader. Responsibilities will include 
assisting the directorate and the consultant team in:  
(i)  reviewing  and  updating  the  communications  strategy  of  MFAC  and  the 
directorate;  
(ii)  supporting implementation of the communications strategy, including preparation 
of communications products including press releases and photos; 
(iii)  preparing Tetum versions of key TA documents, including training and operating 
manuals and guides, and project reports; 
(iv)  providing Tetum–English interpreter services to a high professional standard for 
TA activities;  
(v)  leading information dissemination in Tetum for the TA activities, including to 
government  agencies,  development  partners,  the  media,  and  civil  society 
representatives;  
(vi)  assisting in user consultations, including focus group discussions;  
(vii)  assisting in preparing reports and providing input related to contract management 
under the TA; and  
(viii)  undertaking other tasks as required by the team leader.  
 
13.   Reporting  requirements.  The team leader will be responsible for the quality of all 
reports, documentation, and submissions produced under the TA to a publishable and high 
professional standard. All reports required to explain and assess TA activities are to be in 
English and suitable for public circulation. With the support of TA consultants, the team leader 
will submit an inception report, monthly progress reports, a midterm report, a draft final report, 
and a final report to the government and ADB.

author_page:
CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency of Timor-Leste is the United States dollar.  
 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  MFAC  –  Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation 
  REI  –  regional economic integration 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
   
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  X. Yao, Pacific Department (PARD) 
   
Team leader  S. Rosenthal, Country Director, Timor-Leste Resident Mission (TLRM), 
PARD 
Team member  M. Caldeira, Senior Operations Assistant, TLRM (PARD) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
